This distinctive enzymatic activity of UGT75AJ2 makes it a promising candidate for the biosynthesis of natural blue pigments and high-value flavonoid glycosides ( 43 44 1 RESULTS Functional characterization of UGT75AJ2 and bioactivity verification of its glycosylation products Vaccinium corymbosum V. corymbosum 45 O V. corymbosum 1 18 Fig. 1, A and B Fig. 1. Functional characterization of UGT75AJ2. ( A O 1 B 1 1a 1b O C 1a 1b D O 18 E 18 18a 18c O O F 18a 18c In particular, two glucosylated derivatives (labeled 1a 1b Fig. 1C + m z Fig. 1D O 1a 1b O O O 18a 18b O O Fig. 1, E and F The hydroxyl group in the chemical structure of flavonoids has been demonstrated to play a crucial role in their anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and hypoglycemic activities. However, it has been observed that the hydroxyl groups at positions C-3′ and C-7 can attenuate their biological activities to some extent ( 46 O O O Despite the fact that a few glycosyltransferases have been reported to catalyze 3′- O O 33 34 47 Identifying mutational hotspots for UGT75AJ2 by in silico approach To enhance the catalytic performance of UGT75AJ2, we embarked on a tailored FRISM evolutionary strategy (fig. S6), which started with an in silico approach, using AlphaFold2, RoseTTAFold All-Atom, and homology modeling for predicting the enzyme’s atomic structure, subsequently validated through all-atom explicit solvent molecular dynamics (MD) simulations (figs. S7 to S9). Molecular docking was then applied to discern ~70 critical mutation hotspots (fig. S10), facilitating the creation of a targeted mutation library by assessing the binding energy alterations of these identified sites. As shown in Fig. 2A ΔΔ G mut ¯ t ΔΔ G mut ¯ Fig. 2B Fig. 2C Fig. 2D Fig. 2. Virtual screening of potential mutation hotspots for UGT75AJ2. ( A ΔΔ G mut ¯ ΔΔ G mut ¯ > B ΔΔ G mut ¯ ΔΔ G mut ¯ > C D ΔΔ G mut ¯ > Enhancing UGT75AJ2 catalytic activity To enhance the catalytic activity of UGT75AJ2, we targeted these 34 hotspot residues identified for mutation to alanine using site-directed mutagenesis, assessing the impact on catalytic performance toward substrate C3G ( 1 Fig. 3B 1 O 1a Fig. 3. Tailored directed evolution strategy to enhance UGT75AJ2 activity. ( A B 1 1a C 1a D 1a E 1a F G UGTs are recognized for catalyzing S N 48 17 Leveraging the mutant Mut1-1 (S367A), which showed the most significant enhancement in catalytic activity in the initial round of alanine scanning, we targeted the V274A mutant, which showed sevenfold catalytic activity improvement compared to the WT, for further ISM (fig. S17). This approach led to the construction of 19 mutants, built upon the Mut1-1 template. Among these, the double mutant Mut2-1 (S367A/V274A) showcased an impressive 2.5- and 45-fold increase in activity over Mut1-1 and WT, respectively ( Fig. 3C 49 50 82 82 Fig. 3D k cat K m In the evolutionary process, mutations that enhance protein functionality tend to be naturally selected and conserved ( 51 42 O 132 Fig. 3, E and F V. corymbosum Aralia cordata O Escherichia coli O O To further elucidate the mechanisms of improved catalytic activity of UGT75AJ2, we performed molecular docking and MD simulations. The results revealed an increase in hydrogen bonding and hydrophobic interactions within the Mut4-1 complex compared to the WT complex (figs. S28; S29, A to D; and S30 to S31), mainly due to the contributions of the mutated residues S367A, V274A, and I132T. These interactions helped stabilize the enzyme’s catalytic conformation. MD simulations further highlighted the stability of Mut4-1 in the presence of UDP-Glc and C3G, surpassing that of the WT complex (fig. S29, E and F). In addition, the active site of Mut4-1 exhibited increased flexibility, particularly in four N-terminal loops (loop2, loop5, loop7, and loop9), implying an improved capacity for substrate binding (fig. S29G). This structural flexibility was complemented by a closer proximity between C3G 3′-O atom and UDP-Glc anomeric C atom in Mut4-1 compared to WT (fig. S29H). Volume measurements confirmed that the active site pocket of Mut4-1 was larger than that of WT, thus favoring the ligand interactions (fig. S29, I and J). These collective structural adjustments significantly amplify UGT75AJ2’s catalytic activity in the Mut4-1 variant. To determine the most favorable conditions for UGT75AJ2 catalysis, we tested a variety of substrates, including C3G ( 1 O 4 O 5 O 7 O 9 O 12 2+ Broadening the substrate spectrum of UGT75AJ2 and its Mut4-1 mutant To assess the substrate versatility of UGT75AJ2 and its enhanced variant Mut4-1 in glycosylation reactions, we evaluated 36 flavonoids with pharmaceutical potential ( Fig. 4B 1 13 14 17 18 21 22 24 25 28 29 30 31 36 Fig. 4B Fig. 4A O O Fig. 4A 23 31 36 23 52 53 14 18 Fig. 4. Substrate scope of WT and Mut4-1. ( A 1 13 14 17 18 21 22 24 25 28 29 30 31 36 B Expanding sugar donor compatibility of UGT75AJ2 To further explore the sugar donor specificity of UGT75AJ2, we assessed its activity with UDP-galactose (UDP-Gal), UDP–glucuronic acid (UDP-GlcA), UDP- N 1 15 Fig. 5, D and E Fig. 5A Fig. 5B Fig. 5C 1 Fig. 5D Fig. 5E Fig. 5. Sequence-based protein engineering improvement of the sugar donor selectivity of UGT75AJ2. ( A B C D E 1 15 F G N H 1 I 1 J 15 Molecular docking of UDP-GlcNAc and UGT75AJ2 revealed that F366 was positioned near the 2- N Fig. 5, F and G Fig. 5H Fig. 5H Fig. 5, I and J 15 Fig. 5J Further MD simulations of the WT complex, incorporating sugar donors and acceptors, demonstrated that the crucial catalytic residue H17 engaged in unwanted hydrogen bonding with the glycosyl donor (figs. S75 to S80, A and G), which hindered the formation of the His-acceptor dyad intermediate, thus preventing WT from engaging with various glycosyl donors. In contrast, within the GHG mutant (S14G/F366H/S367G), not only was the substrate able to achieve a correct catalytic alignment with H17, reinforcing the protein’s structural integrity (figs. S75 to S80), but the proximity between the nucleophilic oxygen and the anomeric carbon also significantly decreased in the GHG complex relative to the WT (figs. S75 to S80, E, F, K, and L). These alterations enhanced the glycosyl donor versatility observed in the GHG mutant. Enhancing the regioselectivity of UGT75AJ2 To further assess the regioselectivity of WT UGT75AJ2 and its Mut4-1 mutant, enzyme activity assays were conducted using C3G ( 1 18 O O A thorough investigation into the active site pinpointed 18 residues suitable for an exhaustive series of saturated virtual mutations ( Fig. 6, A and C Fig. 6, D and E 54 55 Fig. 6F 1 18 Fig. 6. The regioselectivity modification of UGT75AJ2. ( A B C D E G mut F G H 1 I 18 J K The HPLC results of mutant library screening revealed that the I132E and S367F mutants exhibited highly regioselective activity, facilitating 3′- O O 1 Fig. 6, H and J O O In addition, mutants I132E and S367G showed strict selectivity for the 3′- O O- 18 Fig. 6, I and K O 1 O 18 18 O O 18 O O Subsequently, to refine mutants with superior regioselectivity and efficiency for substrate C3G ( 1 Fig. 6G O Fig. 6, H and J O 17 O 75 178 188 1 O For enhancing 7- O O 1b Fig. 6J O 17 273 367 112 O DISCUSSION Emerging research underscores the medicinal potential of flavonoid glycosides and their derivatives due to their robust biological activities and chemical stability ( 19 O 56 57 O O 30 V. corymbosum O O To address these challenges, we first designed a targeted structure-guided directed evolution strategy to optimize the UGT75AJ2 enzyme for efficient glycosylation applications ( 32 35 1 K m K m k cat K m −1 −1 et al. 58 O K m k cat K m −1 −1 −1 −1 58 et al. 59 K m k cat K m −1 −1 59 et al. 60 K m k cat K m −1 −1 −1 −1 60 Moreover, the high degree of sugar donor promiscuity is as important as the broader substrate spectrum of glycosyltransferases in natural drug discovery ( 61 59 62 O 63 O 64 O O 65 67 68 69 Despite these advances, our observations revealed that the WT UGT75AJ2 is restricted to using only UDP-Glc. Although the Mut4-1 mutant can act on other sugar donors like UDP-Gal, UDP-GlcNAc, and UDP-Xyl, its transfer rates remain suboptimal. This study represented the comprehensive structure-guided sequence analysis of the sugar donor binding region in UGT75AJ2. By comparing residues across five zones (A to E) with those of other highly promiscuous glycosyltransferases, we were able to engineer the UGT75AJ2 enzyme to construct the triple mutant S14G/F366H/S367G. This mutant showed significantly improved catalytic activities over Mut4-1, particularly with apigenin ( 15 In addition to enhancing donor promiscuity, engineering the regioselectivity of glycosyltransferase to meet the requirements for specific site glycosylation is also a major challenge in the natural drug synthesis field ( 20 25 70 35 In response, we further devised a strategy to engineer UGT75AJ2’s regioselectivity using a FRISM-based combinatorial mutagenesis approach, eliminating the need for large mutation libraries. Key active site residues identified through virtual screening were mutated to alter the pocket’s conformation and properties. In particular, residues 132 and 367 were pinpointed as crucial for regioselectivity, leading to further saturation mutagenesis. Combinatorial mutagenesis on the highest regioselectivity mutants yielded two triple mutants, Y75E/F185Y/I132T and L112F/M273E/S367D, with 99 and 85% selectivity for the 3′- O O 1 O O O 1 O O O 71 72 18 Overall, this study marks a notable leap forward in the field of O MATERIALS AND METHODS Reagents Cyanidin-3,5- O 1c 16 O 16a O 19a 21 22 O 14c O O 18a O 18c 23 O 24a O 22b 28 O 27a 15 17 19 24 25 30 14 18 20 27 d RNA sequencing analysis and annotation Total RNA was extracted from matured or unmatured blueberry ( V. corymbosum https://www.bgi.com/global/service/dr-tom Phylogenetic analysis of UGT75AJ2 The phylogenetic tree was conducted using the neighbor-joining method based on ClustalW multiple alignments using MEGA 7 software. The figure of the phylogenetic tree was embellished through the online website iTOL ( https://itol.embl.de/ Rational design of mutations in UGT75AJ2 All the selected active residues were separately mutated to alanine using primers (table S7) containing GCG codon at specified sites. ISM was conducted using degenerate primer NNK (table S11) on plasmid template from the last round of mutation. The other specific primers for site-directed or combined mutagenesis are provided in tables S8 to S10, S12, and S13. All different mutants were created by the recombinant vector pET32a-UGT75AJ2. First, the whole mutant plasmids were obtained by PCR using KOD One PCR Master Mix-Blue-polymerase and primers. Next, the PCR product was incubated with DMT enzyme (TransGen, Beijing) at 30°C for 1 hour. Electrophoresis of the incubated product was identified, and the product was purified by gel extraction kit. The mutant PCR product was sent to Tsingke Biotechnology for sequencing. Last, the pure PCR product was transformed into DMT competent cells, followed by heterologous expression as described above. The catalytic activity of mutants was measured in 200 μl of the reaction buffer, including 50 μg of purified mutants, 0.5 mM acceptor, 1.0 mM UDP-Glc, and 50 mM tris-HCl. A unit of enzyme activity was defined as the amount of enzyme required to consume 1 μmol of substrate per minute. Statistical analysis Statistical analysis was conducted using Prism 8.0 (GraphPad, USA). Data were presented as means ± standard deviation of at least three independent experiments. The normality and the homogeneity of variance were checked by Shapiro-Wilk test before applying Student’s t t P Acknowledgments We thank Y. Liu from the College of Life Sciences at Zhejiang University for technical assistance with the nuclear magnetic resonance analysis. We are also grateful for the assistance provided by L. Wang in performing the MD simulation analysis.
